original: BERGSTRÖM, Hilding Olof Vidar, Civilingenjör, Stockholm, f Avesta 8/11 80 av ingenjör A Bergström o Maria Dahl, gm Ingrid Bergman. Studex Karlst 99, ex KTH 02. Anst f utredn v Jernkont 02, koln.ing där 04, förest koln.lab (sen Frn Koln.lab upa) 07, insp Jernk o stat kolaresk. Konsult o konstr, verksamh sed. 04 Utf anläggn f koin o härvid erh biprodukt, klarlagt förlopp v mil-koln o inf skorst.milan, utf anläggn f tillv.-tag o förädl av flyt harts, terp.olja mfl bi-prod v cellul.kokn, utr vatt- o luftföroren.-fråg spec f sulfatcellul.fabr, inf nya metod f värmeekon v sulfatfabrrs sodahus, konstr o uppf kolonnapp, indunstn.app, utf utred öv probl f träavfalls tillg.gör Resor: Tyskl, österr-Ung, Frankr, Schweiz, Balk, Ryssl, USA. Publ ett 200-t skr. RVO, LIVA, LVS.
translated: BERGSTRÖM, Hilding Olof Vidar, Civil Engineer, Stockholm, born in Avesta 8/11 1880 to engineer A Bergström and Maria Dahl, married to Ingrid Bergman. Graduate from Karlst 1899, graduated from KTH 1902. Employed as researcher at Jernkont from 1902, became a coal engineer in 1904, appointed as head of the coal lab (later promoted from coal lab) in 1907, inspector at Jernkont and state coal school. Consultant and designer, active since 1904. Carried out the construction of a coal oven and obtained a byproduct, clarified the process of coal burning and chimney soot. Executed the construction of production and refinement of floating resin, turpentine oil, and other byproducts of cellulose cooking. Studied water and air pollution issues, particularly focused on the sulfate cellulose factory. Implemented new methods for heat economy in the soda house of the sulfate factory, designed and built a column apparatus and an evaporation apparatus. Conducted research on the utilization of wood waste. Traveled to Germany, Austria-Hungary, France, Switzerland, the Balkans, Russia, and the United States. Published about 200 books and articles. Received the Royal Order of Vasa, the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences' Gold Medal, and the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences' Gold Small Medal.

structured.name: Hilding Olof Vidar Bergström
structured.description: Civil engineer Hilding Olof Vidar Bergström was born on November 8, 1880, in Avesta, Sweden. He was the son of engineer A Bergström and Maria Dahl. He married Ingrid Bergman. Bergström graduated from Karlst in 1899 and later from KTH in 1902. He worked as a researcher at Jernkont from 1902 to 1904, then became a coal engineer. In 1907, he was appointed head of the coal lab and later worked as an inspector at Jernkont and state coal school. Bergström was a well-known consultant and designer and had a long list of achievements in various fields such as coal burning, chimney soot, cellulose cooking, water and air pollution, and wood waste utilization. He traveled extensively to countries including Germany, Austria-Hungary, France, Switzerland, the Balkans, Russia, and the United States. Bergström published around 200 books and articles and received prestigious honors like the Royal Order of Vasa, the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences' Gold Medal, and the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences' Gold Small Medal.
